org_midgardproject_projectsite_document.title: Midgard MVC request process
org_midgardproject_projectsite_document.content: <div><div>Basic building blocks:</div><div><ul><li><b>Application</b>: a configuration file describing the components and other settings used in a Midgard MVC website</li><li><b>Component</b>: a PHP module intended to run as part of a web application. For example: a news listing. Provides routes, controllers and templates</li><li><b>Library</b>: a PHP module that can be called by other modules to perform some task. Does not run as part of a website. For example: a form validation library</li><li><b>Service</b>: a standardized interface to access a given functionality. For example: authentication</li><li><b>Provider</b>: a standardized interface to access given information. For example: hierarchy. The difference between Services and Providers is that Services perform tasks while Providers merely provide access to a particular type of data</li></ul></div><h3>Bootstrapping</h3></div><div><ul><li>Midgard MVC bootstrap PHP file (framework.php) is called</li><li>Midgard MVC bootstrap registers an autoloader (midgardmvc_core::autoload()) that will be used for loading the necessary PHP files</li><li>Front controller (midgardmvc_core::get_instance()) starts</li><li>Front controller loads configuration from a configuration provider</li><li>Front controller loads component providers specified in configuration</li><li>Front controller loads hierarchy providers specified in configuration</li></ul></div><div><h3>Request processing</h3></div><div><ul><li>A request object gets populated with the current HTTP request parameters</li><li>Process injectors are called, if the loaded components registered any</li><li>Request object uses hierarchy providers to determine what components handle the request</li><li>Request object loads the necessary component</li><li>Front controller passes the request object to the Dispatcher</li><li>Dispatcher dispatches the request to the component controller class, passing it the request object</li><li>Component controller class executes and sets data to the request object</li></ul></div><div><h3>Templating</h3></div><div><ul><li>Front controller loads template providers specified in configuration</li><li>Template injectors are called, if the loaded components registered any</li><li>Front controller determines template to be used with the request</li><li>Front controller uses a template provider to generate request output</li><li>Request output is sent to browser</li></ul></div><div><h3>Midgard MVC Front Controller</h3></div><div><p>The Midgard MVC Front Controller midgardmvc_core is responsible for catching a HTTP request and ensuring it gets processed and templated. The Front Controller implements a Singleton pattern, meaning that only a single Midgard MVC Front Controller is available at a time.</p></div><div><p>The Front Controller is accessible via:</p></div><div><pre>$mvc = midgardmvc_core::get_instance();</pre></div><div><h3>Midgard MVC Dispatcher</h3></div><div><p>The Midgard MVC Dispatcher receives a Request object and instantiates and calls the necessary Components and Controllers, and calls their action methods.</p></div><div><p>The Dispatcher is accessible via:</p></div><div><pre>$dispatcher = midgardmvc_core::get_instance()-&gt;dispatcher;<br />$dispatcher-&gt;dispatch($request);</pre></div><div><p>Depending on what Controllers and action methods were called (if any), this will either return the Request object with some new data populated or cause an Exception to be thrown.</p></div>
